The hand gun. Humans are separated from other species in the animal kingdom, largely by our ability to make tools. Tools can be thought of as any device that provides utility for fulfilling a human desire or need. The invention of gun powder gave rise to the rifle: a tool of significant utility. Humans cannot compete in combat with other apex predators absent tools to gain advantage. Spears, clubs, knives, snares, traps; all have been useful for humans in their confrontations with large, dangerous animals. Rifles proved the ultimate tool for hunting large prey and protection from apex predators. Before the invention of the rifle, packs of wolves, sometimes in numbers greater than thirty individuals, ruled the night, whereever the habitat spawned them. In 18th century Russia it was highly hazardous to venture out at night because large packs of wolves routinely tore humans apart enroute. The rifle allowed for the culling of large wolf packs and therefore mitigating the threat such packs posed to our safety. Rifles also proved useful for hunting large animals suitable for eating. But hand guns serve no such purpose.. Their sole utility is to kill other human beings in close combat. They are much less accurate at the distances often required to hunt large prey. Hand guns are , as I call them, Human Being Killing Machines. They automate the dispensing of another human being, and thats about all they are good for. While it unfortunately, on occasion, becomes necessary to forge into battle, war is, more often than not a gross misuse of manpower and resources. Most wars end with the parties involved finally sitting down together to work out the terms under which they will coexist peacefully in the future. In other words: the warring nations eventually resolve to coexist peacefully, deciding upon terms agreeable to all parties, so, since diplomacy always provides the solution to the problems nations confront, why not cut to the chase and use diplomats to settle disputes in all cases? But I digress somewhat. My point is that it is rifles, not handguns, that play the dominant role in modern warfare. Side arms are carried into battle and are useful in policing nations too. But in every instance the hand guns utility is reduced to that of a Human Being Killling Machine. And in my opinion, killing other human beings is something mankind is better off not participating in. We need to rely upon our reasoning skills to resolve disputes that arise amongst our people's..We are after all, all one big family. At the end of the day we share in common the title: Earthlings. And it is my view that we should do all we can to avoid killing one another. It is an occasional necessary evil, But ultimately it remains an evil.

Atomic Bomb  A nuclear weapon of the “Fat Man” type, the plutonium implosion type detonated over Nagasaki.60 inches in diameter and 128 inches long, the weapon weighed about 10,000 pounds and had a yieldapproximating 21,000 tons of high explosives (Copy from U.S. National Archives, RG 77-AEC). source Weapons whose explosive output is exclusively from fission reactions are commonly referred to as atomic bombs or atom bombs. These bombs are the deadliest invented so far. The “Little Boy” and the “Fat Man” (a gun-type weapon and an implosion-type weapon, used in the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki) have already shown the world the destruction that an atomic bomb can wreak upon the world. Developed as a part of the Manhattan Project (a research and development project that produced the first nuclear weapons) during the World War II by the United States. On August 6, 1945, at 8:16 a.m. Japanese time, an American B-29 bomber, the Enola Gay, drops the world’s first atom bomb, over the city of Hiroshima. Approximately 80,000 people are killed as a direct result of the blast, and another 35,000 are injured. At least another 60,000 would be dead by the end of the year from the effects of the fallout. It remains the deadliest invention and a constant threat to world peace.  A nuclear weapon of the “Little Boy” type, the uranium gun-type detonated over Hiroshima. It is 28 inches in diameter and 120 inches long. “Little Boy” weighed about 9,000 pounds and had a yield approximating 15,000 tons of high explosives. (Copy from U.S. National Archives, RG 77-AEC). source  A mushroom cloud rises from Hiroshima, Japan, on August 6, 1945, in the first use of an atomic bomb during World War II. A second bomb was dropped three days later on Nagasaki, and Japan surrendered August 14. source

For me, it has to be robots and artificial intelligence. I'm not sure if my fear of them is rational, or if it's more of a phobia. It just seems really dumb to make a machine, with their capacity to malfunction, and then give it a mind of its own. Some people will say that there are the famous 3 Laws of Robotics that are meant to protect people. But how is a malfunctioning machine going to adhere to any programming? Connect it to an oversight system? Well, then it could get hacked. Even if it weren't connected it could be hacked, or tampered with, or sabotaged. Also, how many ways could someone get around the rules? I'm sure someone has been thinking about this already and has figured out how to manipulate the rules for their own personal gain. Then again, what would stop someone bent on evil doings from creating their own AI with no rules? So essentially, a life sized human figure made of metal with the strength and ability to break down your door and squeeze the life out of you (if so inclined by design or accident) is a reality. They aren't yet able to pass as humans, looking and acting in a way that would make them indistinguishable from us, but they will be. I'd guess that within 20 years we will see really lifelike robots. I've already seen some fairly good ones, but still obviously machines. And there may be some perfectly harmless, even extremely beneficial, uses for a lifelike robot, but there are also some terrifying ones.

I have studied science and technology all my life, and wrote term papers on nuclear weapons. I attended training as a Nuclear Biological Chemical Defense specialist in the military and learned the first hand effects of nuclear weapons. I have studied the modern day nuclear accidents such as Chernobyl, Ukraine and Fukushima, Japan and learned the first hand effects of nuclear power if not properly managed. I think of the famous line that always goes through my head from the Spider Man movies, "With great power comes great responsibility." Nothing is a better example of that thought than nuclear power. It could be the blessing that saves the planet from the dangers of fossil fuels and the dependency on foreign oil. It could be the curse that destroys us as well if used as a weapon by terrorists.

The internal combustion engine Prior to this, engines had to be fairly heavy and attached to massive machines that were only useful for carrying large numbers of people or large amounts of goods. The ICE allowed engines to become smaller, separated them from the need to be attached to a power source all the time, and allowed the exploitation of ultra volatile fuels like gasoline, diesel and kerosene. So you could have one of your own. Or, unfortunately, several tens of millions of people could afford to have one all of their own. Instead of, you know, taking the train or something.  Now, for individuals, this was a positive boon. For society as a whole, not so much. Forget about climate change for a minute - places with a lot of these things became polluted - air pollution, soil pollution (from leaking gas tanks), space pollution (the need for wide roads and lots of parking spaces), etc.
